about.subTitle: About me
about.title: Let me introduce myself
about.description: Hello! I'm David Pessoa, Software Developer, Computer Science graduate from Mackenzie Presbyterian University and Electronics Technician from Liceu de Artes e Ofícios de São Paulo.
about.aspirations: I aim to work as a Software Engineer, improving my skills in web, software and mobile applications, while gaining experience in software architecture, project management.

resume.title: My Experiences

20DASH.description: At the end of 2025, I worked as a Full Stack Developer intern at 20DASH. On the back end, I collaborated on the development of microservices-based systems using AWS Lambda (serverless) with the Chalice Framework, integrated with a PostgreSQL database hosted on AWS RDS. On the front end, I contributed to interface development using React.js with Vite.js, focusing on reusable components, best practices in state management, and seamless API integration.

elevential.description: During my internship at Elevential, I worked as a Python programmer contributing to a project with Django framework and integrated with a PostgreSQL database for database management. Additionally, I contributed to front-end development using Javascript and the Bootstrap framework

mackleaps.description: In 2023, I worked as a volunteer at Mackleaps Junior Company to develop the front-end (using HTML, CSS, Javascript and React.js) of a web application to display weather data from stations located on the Mackenzie campus. Click here to see the website.

dentalClinic.title: Dental Clinic Website
dentalClinic.description: I developed a website using Next.js as part of a Web and Mobile Development course project. The application includes a homepage presenting the clinic’s services, patient reviews, and profiles of dental professionals. The entire website was built with a strong focus on responsiveness, ensuring a good user experience across different screen sizes and devices. Click here to check out the web site!

samsai.title: SamsAI
samsai.description: As my undergraduate capstone project, I developed, together with my colleagues, an application using Django and integrated with Maritaca AI’s Sabiá-3 artificial intelligence model to support the Judiciary. The application is also integrated with a Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) system to provide legal context to the model, enabling it to answer users’ questions. The project aims to provide lawyers and judges with a tool to help them handle the large volume of ongoing cases and reduce delays in case resolution, thereby streamlining judicial processes

weatherStation.title: Weather Station
weatherStation.description: In order to develop my skills with the Django framework in Python (as well as some front-end skills), I decided to create this application, which retrieves data from the weather station of a selected city and displays it on the screen. The data is obtained from WeatherAPI.

bank.title: Bank of Django
bank.description: Like the Weather Station project, this is another personal project aimed at improving my skills with the Django framework and front-end development. In this application, users can create an account and log in to perform withdrawals, deposits, and even PIX transfers, which can be viewed in the transaction history.

concierge.title: The Concierge
concierge.description: During the first semester of the Computer Science program at Mackenzie (2022), I developed a remote-controlled cart operated via a mobile application. Its purpose was to carry objects for the user, reducing physical effort. I named it Concierge, inspired by the hotel staff responsible for carrying guests’ luggage. On its top, the cart features a scale to monitor the carried weight, which is displayed on a front-facing screen. The Concierge also indicates when the weight exceeds the allowed limit.

parkingLot.title: Automated Parking Lot
parkingLot.description: In the final year of the Electronics program at Liceu (2020), I built a scale model of an automated parking system as my capstone project. The model consisted of a parking lot in which light sensors installed in each parking space detected the presence of a vehicle through changes in light intensity. This allowed each space to be indicated as available (green LED) or occupied (red LED). In addition, the project included radio-frequency sensors to detect the tags used by elderly users, helping to prevent designated parking spaces from being improperly occupied. Watch the video.
